comments.commentBody: This is fun! Thanks

You are better than I.  I have been on I-80 in Iowa 3 or 4 times in the past few months and any kind of distraction (like an audio book) seems like taking your life in your hands.  Without a doubt, the most unpredictable drivers I have ever seen (I have driven in 42 of the lower 48) and at high speed to boot.  Maybe you can take refuge in the world's  largest truck-stop in Walcott Iowa for a while.  Good luck to you.

Thanks so much for your report. I'm continuously amazed at the effort NYT reporters must make to get their stories by deadline. I love this kind of inside information and detail you describe in getting your story. Well done for you and The New York Times!

Go with "Behind the Beautiful Forevers." It's a great book. I'd also recommend anything by Michael Lewis. "The Big Short", "Boomerang" and "Flash Boys" should be required reading for anyone running for President.

Fun insight into the less glamorous aspects of political reporting. But is there any room for candy on the listening list (not that Ms. Chozick hasn't listed some succulent vegetables). A few slightly more frivolous recommendations that are terrific audiobooks:
--All three of J.K. Rowling's Cormoran Strike mystery novels written under her Robert Galbraith pseudonym;
--"Innocent," by Scott Turow -- the many-years-later sequel to his blockbuster 1980s hit, "Presumed Innocent;"
--"11/22/63" by Stephen King -- wonderful trip down a rabbithole of historical fiction with a twist, and you don't have to be a King devotee to like it;
--"An Officer and a Spy" -- great Robert Harris historical thriller re-examining the Dreyfus affair in late nineteenth century France;
--"The Ghost Writer," another great Robert Harris political thriller unless you've already seen the (excellent) movie -- no doubt there's some time for Netflix in those Iowa hotel rooms?

Good luck and happy listening!

I prefer to read rather than listen, but here are 5 excellent ones available on Audible:

The Essential Bernie Sanders & His Vision for America by Jonathan Tahini
Moyers on Democracy by Bill Moyers
This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. the Climate by Naomi Klein
Nemesis: The Last Days of the American Republic by Chalmers Johnson
Griftopia: Bubble Machines, Vampire Squids, and the Long Con That Is Breaking America by Matt Taibbi

and one more for bonus:

The Best Democracy Money Can Buy: The Truth About Corporate Cons, Globalization, & High-Finance Fraudsters by Greg Palast

It is a long road to next November.

I'm an Audible junkie too. The longer the book, the better. I started with NPR, migrated to podcasts. Now its Audible. I can't even walk the dog or mow the lawn without it. Mostly nonfiction. In cold blood was great.
I can't seem to finish a printed book. Real reading makes me nod off. Since I discovered Audible, I've made a significant dent in my 'wished i read but never did' list

All of these are audiobook memoirs that I recommend:

Elsewhere by Richard Russo
Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius by Dave Eggers
Let's Pretend this Never Happened by Jenny Lawson
Wild by Cheryl Strayed.

Don't forget public libraries offer many wonderful eaudiobooks for free. Audible is lovely but very expensive. There are waitlists for the current best sellers from the library but many classics available at the moment. I just finished listening to Wallace Stegner's Big Rock Candy Mountain, so good. An all time favorite is the Dark Materials Trilogy by Philip Pullman. Jeremy Irons reading of Lolita is amazing.

And if your own library doesn't have a good selection of ebooks, you can buy a year's membership at the Philadelphia Free Library for $50 and digitally check out books anywhere in the country.  Not that we need this in Phoenix; our library system is excellent.

Local libraries offer an incredible range of books - I totally agree with your comment.  I survive a long daily commute by listening to a wide variety of books, and have discovered authors I never would have had the time to read.
What a great hint -thanks!

HEAR YE! HEAR YE! Step right up and get your electronic downloadable audio books and e-books at your local public library!!! You work for the NY Times, you may have heard of the New York Public Library....why pitch for Audible--Bezos own Washington Post, not the Times...NYPL (and many other public libraries) has "The Immortal Lives of Henrietta Lacks"...now just think how smart you can feel, covering a democrat and utilizing an institution devoted to the public good....NY Times doesn't have to pay for your Audible...Your account manager can thank me, a public librarian for saving the NY Times some money today.
Great Courses is Amazing too! Used to listen to that when they would sell CDs! An entire course in 44 minutes! Without fail, a terrific source of so many classes!

I want to put in a plug for my favorite car-time listening, the courses from the Teaching Company (now labeled as Great Courses). I check them out from my local library, but they are also available on Audible.com You might want to start with one that is especially relevant, "Cycles of American Political Thought" But the range of courses covers philosophy, history from ancient times to today, science, religion, medicine, sociology, and more. I've seldom been disappointed by a course, and while I can't say I'm as focused on the material as I'd be if I was reading a book at home, it has been a rewarding and informative way to spend time commuting.

Liked, enjoyed might be a better word, article but while I'm OK that it featured pic of IA (where I currently reside), a typically under represented area in the FlyOver US . . . even in the general area represented it was not a particularly representative pic. Unless of course one's exposure is solely via Interstates which tend to look remarkably similar no matter where in US one is. Walcott, identified in the caption, is roughly 13 miles from Davenport on the Mississippi River (with bluffs north & south of the Urban area . . . parts of gentrified, repurposed, parts of that urban area on both sides of the River (Il & IA) would not be out of place in Hollywood movies set in Philly or Brooklyn. Driving along any not interstate routes from Walcott to City Center Davenport (well right at the RR tracks paralleling the Mississippi, each route visually distinct with only a minute or two separating travel time) would present very different visual impressions than any shot along the Intersate. One of those routes would follow Depression Era 'Lincoln' Highway, US6 (which I80 more or less replaced). To understand even marginally what goes on inside IA every four years it does help to both see I80 (& the tiny airports) and Walcott, Hwy 6, Kimberly Road, and since 9/11 what is officially called 160th street.

(& personally if I had a choice (& couple million surplus $s) I'd prefer to reside in NYC, but that's a different story)
These prison guards should be thrown in with the general population at this prison that could serve as a decent deterrent to this type of behavior by the staff.

Great reporting ! Please do not let up.
It takes persistence and light to clean up some messes
I loved you in the Globe, Wesley and am delighted that you will be writing for the Times. Like another read mentioned, the Times is our "other paper!"  All the best in 2016!

Friday, December 27th, 1963
North London
Seven Sisters Road
Astoria Cinema - Finsbury Park
She Loves You/I Want to Hold Your Hand

From hereon out Mrs. Clinton would do well to respond to every one of The Donald's insults by simply using the sound of a toilet flushing.  That's about all his slings and arrows are worth in any case.
"A temporary aberration"?  Too late for that; he's been around for nearly seventy years. Time for him to be committed to the Old Lunatics Home.

I made this last year and it was delicious. I boned it out and cut it flat, doubled the herb/spice mix and spread it over the meat, then rolled it up and tied it. The next day I cooked it in a very slow oven for 7-8 hours. Lovely.

Yes, it's not a problem of angry motorists, drunk biker gangs, children fooling with unsecured firearms, young men spurned by girlfriends, loners looking for media attention, bar patrons, people committing suicide, meth makers protecting their trailer homes, etc. It's blacks, Muslims, and crazies. Sure.

Perhaps, but if the NFL and the National and American Leagues got involved in promoting an end to gun violence, then it would send a message that would be more difficult to ignore. After all, most conservatives and gun owners are not in favor of gun violence - right?

And the CDC should be able and encouraged to study gun violence.

Shame on the NRA funded Republicans for cutting (and threatening to cut) CDC funding.

Like climate change, the Republican response is: if we deny it long enough, we can still reap the contributions from Big Oil and Big Gun.
It it is estimated that 75% of NBA players own handguns.
Sorry but paranoia over "the government" is not helping the issue of gun violence.
The NRA and gun manufacturers are not "against" gun violence. If they were, they would be assistive rather than obstructive in helping to reduce it.
